relation: configure terminal Example: Router# configure terminal
snmp-server packetsize byte-count Example: Router(config)# snmp-server packetsize 512
Enables privileged EXEC mode. Enter your password if prompted.
Exits global configuration mode and returns to privileged EXEC mode.
TableContextTimeStampBeforeTable: {28293=2.    setany -v2c $ADDRESS private mteTriggerValueID.4.106.111.104.110.1 -d 1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.10, 1387=The SNMP manager is a system that controls and monitors the activities of network hosts using SNMP. The most common managing system is an NMS. The term NMS can be applied either to a dedicated device used for network management or to the applications used on such a device. Several network management applications are available for use with SNMP and range from simple CLI applications to applications that use GUIs, such as the CiscoWorks2000 products.}
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {132743=Router(config)# snmp-server host 172.16.1.27 version 2c public, 642994=RFC 2982, 639195=RFC 2213, 637435=RFC 1906, 16136=The Cisco implementation of SNMP uses the definitions of MIB II variables described in RFC 1213 and definitions of SNMP traps described in RFC 1215., 634478=RFC 1098, 230275=Specifies the SNMP engine ID and configures the VRF name traps-vrf for SNMP communications with the remote device at 172.16.20.3., 636872=RFC 1905, 640804=RFC 2570, 630995=RIPv2 Monitoring with SNMP Using the RFC 1724 MIB Extensions feature module, 674943=Â© 2011 Cisco Systems, Inc. All rights reserved., 638733=RFC 2206, 634912=RFC 1157, 163160=Router(config)# snmp-server engineID remote 172.12.15.4 udp-port 120 1a2833c0129a, 27640=SNMPv3 supports RFCs 1901 to 1908, 2104, 2206, 2213, 2214, and 2271 to 2275. For additional information about SNMPv3, see RFC 2570, Introduction to Version 3 of the Internet-standard Network Management Framework (this document is not a standard)., 618175=In the following example, the VRF named "traps-vrf" is configured for the remote server 172.16.20.3:, 230085=Router(config)# snmp-server engineID remote 172.16.20.3 80000009030000B064EFE100, 265285=Enables RFC 1157 generic traps., 641897=RFC 2579, 630835=Cisco IOS implementation of RFC 1724, RIP Version 2 MIB Extensions, 608487=The following example shows how to permit SNMP access to all objects with read-only permission using the community string named public. The router will also send ISDN traps to the hosts 172.16.1.111 and 172.16.1.33 using SNMPv1 and to the host 172.16.1.27 using SNMPv2c. The community string named public is sent with the traps., 642694=RFC 2981, 635922=RFC 1215, 641401=RFC 2578, 638294=RFC 2104, 232037=Router(config)# snmp-server user abcd public remote 172.16.20.3 v3 encrypted auth md5 publichost remotehostusers, 639697=RFC 2214, 636466=RFC 1901, 642294=RFC 2580, 654549=The Entity MIB feature implements support for the Entity MIB module, defined in RFC 2037, and provides a mechanism by which a managed device can advertise its logical components, physical components, and logical to physical mappings., 670677=The SNMPv3 Community MIB Support feature implements support for the SNMP Community MIB (SNMP-COMMUNITY-MIB) module, defined in RFC 2576, in the Cisco IOS software., 634108=RFC 1091, 325633=Router(config)# snmp-server engineID remote 172.16.20.3 vrf traps-vrf, 637860=RFC 1908, 1072=A MIB is a virtual information storage area for network management information and consists of collections of managed objects. Within a MIB are collections of related objects defined in MIB modules. MIB modules are written in the SNMP MIB module language, as defined in STD 58, RFC 2578, RFC 2579, and RFC 2580 (see the "MIBs and RFCs" section for an explanation of Request for Comments (RFC) and Standard documents). Individual MIB modules are also referred to as MIBs; for example, the Interfaces Group MIB (IF-MIB) is a MIB module within the MIB on your system., 640304=RFC 2271, 635346=RFC 1213, 633679=RFC 1067, 255926=Starting with Cisco IOS Release 12.1(3)T, you can globally enable or disable authenticationFailure, linkUp, linkDown, warmStart, and coldStart traps or informs individually. (These traps constitute the "generic traps" defined in RFC 1157.) Note that linkUp and linkDown notifications are enabled by default on specific interfaces but will not be sent unless they are enabled globally.}
textBeforeTable: DETAILED STEPS 4.    exit 3.    snmp-server packetsize byte-count 2.    configure terminal 1.    enable SUMMARY STEPS Perform this task to set the maximum permitted packet size. You can define the maximum packet size permitted when the SNMP agent is receiving a request or generating a reply. Defining the Maximum SNMP Agent Packet Size Exits global configuration mode and returns to privileged EXEC mode.   Router(config)# exit   Example: exit Step 4 Enables system shutdown using the SNMP message reload feature.   Router(config)# snmp-server system-shutdown   Example: snmp-server system-shutdown
textAfterTable: Limiting the Number of TFTP Servers Used via SNMP You can limit the number of TFTP servers used for saving and loading configuration files via SNMP by using an access list. Limiting the use of TFTP servers in this way conserves system resources and centralizes the operation for manageability. Perform this task to limit the number of TFTP servers. SUMMARY STEPS 1.    enable 2.    configure terminal 3.    snmp-server tftp-server-list number DETAILED STEPS   Command or Action Purpose Step 1 enable Example: Router> enable   Enables privileged EXEC mode. Enter your password if prompted.   Step 2 configure terminal Example:
